translated: “Are you tired, Moggallāna? Are you tired, Moggallāna?”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, Sir.”

original: “Tasmātiha, moggallāna, yathāsaññissa te viharato taṁ middhaṁ okkamati, taṁ saññaṁ mā manasākāsi, taṁ saññaṁ mā bahulamakāsi.
analyzed: tasmā ati ha moggallāna yathāsaññissa te viharataḥ tam middham okkamati tam saññam mā manasā akāsi tam saññam mā bahulam akāsi
translated: “Well then, Moggallāna, don’t pay attention to the perception you had when you fell asleep, and don’t develop it.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, moggallāna, vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana ita moggallāna vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha
translated: It’s possible that you’ll give up that drowsiness while you’re paying attention to something else.

original: No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ cetasā anuvitakkeyyāsi anuvicāreyyāsi, manasā anupekkheyyāsi.
analyzed: no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam cetasā anuvitakkeyyāsi anuvicāreyyāsi manasā anupekkheyyāsi
translated: If you don’t give up that drowsiness while you’re paying attention to something else, then you should think and ponder over the Teaching as you’ve heard and learned it.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.🔽No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ kareyyāsi.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha  no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena sajjhāyam kareyyāsi
translated: It’s possible that by doing so you’ll give up that drowsiness.🔽If you’re still drowsy, then recite the Teaching in detail as you’ve heard and learned it.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha
translated: It’s possible that by doing so you’ll give up that drowsiness.

original: No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, ubho kaṇṇasotāni āviñcheyyāsi, pāṇinā gattāni anumajjeyyāsi.
analyzed: no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna ubho kaṇṇa sotāni āviñcheyyāsi pāṇinā gattāni anumajjeyyāsi
translated: If you’re still drowsy, then pull both ears and massage your limbs with your hands.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha
translated: It’s possible that by doing so you’ll give up that drowsiness.

original: No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, uṭṭhāyāsanā udakena akkhīni anumajjitvā disā anuvilokeyyāsi, nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni ullokeyyāsi.
analyzed: no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna uṭṭhāya āsanā udakena akkhīni anumajjitvā disāḥ anuvilokeyyāsi nakkhattāni tāraka rūpāni ullokeyyāsi
translated: If you’re still drowsy, then get up from your seat and splash your face with water. Look around in all directions and look up at the stars and constellations.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha
translated: It’s possible that by doing so you’ll give up that drowsiness.

original: No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, ālokasaññaṁ manasi kareyyāsi, divāsaññaṁ adhiṭṭhaheyyāsi—
analyzed: no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna āloka saññam manasi kareyyāsi divāsaññam adhiṭṭhaheyyāsi
translated: If you don’t give up that drowsiness, then you should focus on the perception of light, determine on the perception of day:

original: yathā divā tathā rattiṁ yathā rattiṁ tathā divā.
analyzed: yathā divā tathā rattim yathā rattim tathā divā
translated: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

original: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṁ cittaṁ bhāveyyāsi.
analyzed: iti vivaṭena cetasā a pariyonaddhena sa pabhāsam cittam bhāveyyāsi
translated: In this way you should develop your mind with an open and unenveloped heart, free of any hindrance.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha
translated: It’s possible that by doing so you’ll give up that drowsiness.

original: No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, pacchāpuresaññī caṅkamaṁ adhiṭṭhaheyyāsi antogatehi indriyehi abahigatena mānasena.
analyzed: no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna pacchāpuresaññī caṅkamam adhiṭṭhaheyyāsi antogatehi indriyehi a bahigatena mānasena
translated: If you don’t give up that drowsiness, then you should determine your walking meditation with a perception of the front and back limits, with your faculties and mind drawn in and not projecting externally.

original: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha.
analyzed: ṭhānam kho pana itam vijjati yat te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha
translated: It’s possible that by doing so you’ll give up that drowsiness.

original: No ce te evaṁ viharato taṁ middhaṁ pahīyetha, tato tvaṁ, moggallāna, dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṁ kappeyyāsi pāde pādaṁ accādhāya sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṁ manasi karitvā.
analyzed: no ce te evam viharato tam middham pahīyetha tatas tva moggallāna dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyam kappeyyāsi pāde pādam accādhāya sataḥ sampajānaḥ uṭṭhāna saññam manasi karitvā
translated: If, while you are living like this, that sloth and torpor have not been given up, then, Moggallāna, you should lie down, but only after having made the resolution to get up at a particular time, and you should be mindful, clearly comprehending, and fully aware of your motives in doing so.

original: Paṭibuddhena ca te, moggallāna, khippaññeva paccuṭṭhātabbaṁ:
analyzed: paṭibuddhena ca te moggallāna khippaññā iva paccuṭṭhātabba
translated: And when you have woken up, you should get up quickly,

original: ‘na seyyasukhaṁ na passasukhaṁ na middhasukhaṁ anuyutto viharissāmī’ti.
analyzed: na seyya sukham na passa sukham na middha sukham anuyuttaḥ viharissāmi iti
translated: thinking: ‘I will not be intent on the pleasure of rest, the pleasure of sloth, the pleasure of sleep.’

original: Evañhi te, moggallāna, sikkhitabbaṁ.
analyzed: evam hi te moggallāna sikkhitabba
translated: You should train thus, Moggallāna.

original: Tasmātiha, moggallāna, evaṁ sikkhitabbaṁ:
analyzed: tasmā ati ha moggallāna evam
translated: Therefore, Moggallāna, you should train yourself thus:

original: ‘na uccāsoṇḍaṁ paggahetvā kulāni upasaṅkamissāmī’ti.
analyzed: na uccā soṇḍam paggahetvā kulāni upasaṅkamissāmi iti
translated: ‘I will not visit families with a conceited manner.’

original: Evañhi te, moggallāna, sikkhitabbaṁ.
analyzed: evam hi te moggallāna sikkhitabba
translated: You should train yourself thus, Moggallāna.

original: Sace, moggallāna, bhikkhu uccāsoṇḍaṁ paggahetvā kulāni upasaṅkamati, santi hi, moggallāna, kulesu kiccakaraṇīyāni.
analyzed: sace moggallāna bhikkhu uccāsoṇḍam paggahetvā kulāni upasaṅkamati santi hi moggallāna kulesu kicca karaṇīyāni
translated: If a bhikkhu visits families with a conceited manner, there are duties to be done in the families,🔽and people do not pay attention to the bhikkhu who has come.

original: Yehi manussā āgataṁ bhikkhuṁ na manasi karonti, tatra bhikkhussa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: yehi manussāḥ āgatam bhikkhum na manasi karonti tatra bhikkhussa evam hoti
translated: The bhikkhu thinks:

original: ‘kosu nāma idāni maṁ imasmiṁ kule paribhindi, virattarūpā dānime mayi manussā’ti.
analyzed: nāma idāni mam imasmin kule viratta rūpāḥ dāni ime mayi manussā ati
translated: ‘Who is it now that is insulting me in this family? People have lost interest in me.’

original: Itissa alābhena maṅkubhāvo, maṅkubhūtassa uddhaccaṁ, uddhatassa asaṁvaro, asaṁvutassa ārā cittaṁ samādhimhā.
analyzed: iti ssa alābhena maṅku bhāvaḥ maṅku bhūtassa uddhaccaḥ uddhatassa asavaraḥ asavutassa ārā cittam samādhimhā
translated: Thus, through lack of gain, he becomes timid. Being timid, he becomes restless. Being restless, he becomes unrestrained. Being unrestrained, his mind falls away from concentration.

original: Tasmātiha, moggallāna, evaṁ sikkhitabbaṁ:
analyzed: tasmā ati ha moggallāna evam
translated: “Therefore, Moggallāna, you should train yourself thus:

original: ‘na viggāhikakathaṁ kathessāmī’ti.
analyzed: na viggāhika katham kathessāmi iti
translated: ‘I will not engage in divisive speech.’

original: Evañhi te, moggallāna, sikkhitabbaṁ.
analyzed: evam hi te moggallāna sikkhitabba
translated: You should train yourself in this way.

original: Viggāhikāya, moggallāna, kathāya sati kathābāhullaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ, kathābāhulle sati uddhaccaṁ, uddhatassa asaṁvaro, asaṁvutassa ārā cittaṁ samādhimhā.🔽Nāhaṁ, moggallāna, sabbeheva saṁsaggaṁ vaṇṇayāmi.🔽Na panāhaṁ, moggallāna, sabbeheva saṁsaggaṁ na vaṇṇayāmi.
analyzed: viggāhikāya moggallāna kathāya sati kathā bāhullam pāṭikaṅkha kathā bāhulle sati uddhacca uddhatassa a savaraḥ a savutassa ārā cittam samādhimhā  na aha moggallāna sabbehi iva sa saggam vaṇṇayāmi  na pana āha moggallāna sabbehi iva sa saggam na vaṇṇayāmi
translated: When there is divisive speech, there is an abundance of talk. When there is an abundance of talk, there is restlessness. When one is restless, there is unrestraint. When one is unrestrained, one’s mind falls away from concentration.🔽“Moggallāna, I do not recommend association for everyone.🔽Nor do I not recommend association for everyone.

original: Sagahaṭṭhapabbajitehi kho ahaṁ, moggallāna, saṁsaggaṁ na vaṇṇayāmi.
analyzed: sagaha ṭṭha pabbajitehi kho aha moggallāna sa saggam na vaṇṇayāmi
translated: I do not recommend association with householders and monastics.

original: Yāni ca kho tāni senāsanāni appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni tathārūpehi senāsanehi saṁsaggaṁ vaṇṇayāmī”ti.🔽Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: yāni ca kho tāni senāsanāni appa saddāni appa nigghosāni vijana vātāni manussa rāhasseyyakāni paṭisallāna sāruppāni tathārūpehi senāsanehi sa saggam vaṇṇayāmi iti  evam vutte āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: I recommend that you associate with those kinds of resting places that are quiet and secluded, far from the madding crowd, undisturbed by sound, with an atmosphere of seclusion, favorable for retreat.”

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti
translated: When this was said, Ven. Mahā Moggallāna said to the Blessed One, “To what extent, lord, is a monk released in the destruction of craving, consummate in the holy life, done with the task, a superior man, a brahmin, a saint, a noble victor in the highest sense?”

original: “Idha, moggallāna, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti:
analyzed: idha moggallāna bhikkhuno sutam hoti
translated: “There is the case where a monk has heard:

analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati
translated: ‘All phenomena are unworthy of attachment.’

translated: If a monk has heard this,

analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati
translated: ‘All phenomena are unworthy of attachment,’

original: So sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhiññāya sabbaṁ dhammaṁ parijānāti. Sabbaṁ dhammaṁ pariññāya yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vediyati sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā.
analyzed: so sabbam dhammam abhijānāti sabbam dhammam abhiññāya sabbam dhammam parijānāti sabbam dhammam pariññāya yam kiñci vedanam vediyati sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā
translated: He directly knows all things. Having directly known all things, he fully understands all things. Having fully understood all things, whatever feeling he feels, whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant,

analyzed: saḥ tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharati virāga anupassī viharati nirodha anupassī viharati paṭinissagga anupassī viharati
translated: he abides contemplating impermanence in those feelings, contemplating fading away in those feelings, contemplating cessation in those feelings, contemplating relinquishment in those feelings.

original: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto virāgānupassī viharanto nirodhānupassī viharanto paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati,
analyzed: so tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharantaḥ virāga anupassī viharantaḥ nirodha anupassī viharantaḥ paṭinissagga anupassī viharantaḥ na kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: As he abides contemplating impermanence in those feelings, contemplating fading away in those feelings, contemplating cessation in those feelings, contemplating relinquishment in those feelings, he does not cling to anything in the world.

original: Ettāvatā kho, moggallāna, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti.🔽Aṭṭhamaṁ.

translated: It is in this way, Moggallana, that a bhikkhu is liberated by the destruction of craving, one who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate security from bondage, the ultimate holy life, the ultimate goal, one who is foremost among gods and humans.”

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 7.62🔽6. Abyākatavagga
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya  abyākata vagga
translated: Thus spoke the Blessed One.🔽The Venerable Mahamoggallana was satisfied and delighted in the Blessed One’s words.🔽The Book of the Elevens

original: Mettasutta
analyzed: mettasutta
translated: The Unanswered Questions

original: “Mā, bhikkhave, puññānaṁ bhāyittha.
analyzed: mā bhikkhave puññānam bhāyittha
translated: “Monks, do not fear merit.

original: Sukhassetaṁ, bhikkhave, adhivacanaṁ yadidaṁ puññāni.
analyzed: sukhassa ita bhikkhave adhivacanam yat idam puññāni
translated: For merit is a term for happiness.

original: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ, bhikkhave, dīgharattaṁ katānaṁ puññānaṁ dīgharattaṁ iṭṭhaṁ kantaṁ manāpaṁ vipākaṁ paccanubhūtaṁ.🔽Satta vassāni mettacittaṁ bhāvesiṁ.
analyzed: abhijānāmi kho pana aha bhikkhave dīgharattam katānam puññānam dīgharattam iṭṭham kantam manāpam vipākam paccanubhūta  satta vassāni metta cittam bhāvesi
translated: I recall having experienced desirable, pleasing, and agreeable fruits of merit for a long time.🔽For seven years I developed the mind of loving-kindness.

original: Satta vassāni mettacittaṁ bhāvetvā satta saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe nayimaṁ lokaṁ punāgamāsiṁ.🔽Saṁvaṭṭamāne sudāhaṁ, bhikkhave, loke ābhassarūpago homi,
analyzed: satta vassāni metta cittam bhāvetvā satta savaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe nayi imam lokam  bhikkhave loke ābhassa rūpago homi
translated: Having developed the mind of loving-kindness for seven years, I did not return to this world for seven eons of contraction and expansion.🔽When the world contracted, I went to the base of the infinity of space;

original: vivaṭṭamāne loke suññaṁ brahmavimānaṁ upapajjāmi.
analyzed: vivaṭṭamāne loke suññam brahmavimānam upapajjāmi
translated: when the world expanded, I was reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, brahmā homi mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī.
analyzed: tatra suda bhikkhave brahmā homi mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūtaḥ vasavattī
translated: There I was Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undisputed Lord, the All-Seeing, the Controller, the Ruler, the Ordainer, the Father of All That Are and Are to Be, the Master, the Lord.

original: Chattiṁsakkhattuṁ kho panāhaṁ, bhikkhave, sakko ahosiṁ devānamindo;
analyzed: chattisa khattum kho pana āha bhikkhave sakkaḥ ahosim devānamindo
translated: Sixty times I was Sakka, ruler of the gods,

original: anekasatakkhattuṁ rājā ahosiṁ cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
analyzed: aneka sata kkhattum rājā ahosim cakkavattī dhammikaḥ dhamma rājā cāturantaḥ vijitāvī janapadatthāvariya ppatto satta ratana samannāgato
translated: and many hundreds of times I was a king, a wheel-turning righteous monarch of the law, conqueror of the four quarters, who had established the security of his realm and possessed the seven treasures.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, imāni satta ratanāni ahesuṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: tassa mayha bhikkhave imāni satta ratanāni ahesu seyyathida
translated: I had these seven treasures:

original: cakkaratanaṁ, hatthiratanaṁ, assaratanaṁ, maṇiratanaṁ, itthiratanaṁ, gahapatiratanaṁ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
analyzed: cakka ratana hatthi ratana assa ratana maṇi ratana itthi ratana gahapati ratana pariṇāyaka ratanam eva sattama
translated: the wheel-treasure, the elephant-treasure, the horse-treasure, the jewel-treasure, the woman-treasure, the steward-treasure, and the counsellor-treasure as the seventh.

original: Parosahassaṁ kho pana me, bhikkhave, puttā ahesuṁ sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
analyzed: parosahassam kho pana me bhikkhave puttāḥ ahesum sūrāḥ vīraṅga rūpāḥ para sena pamaddanāḥ
translated: I had more than a thousand sons, heroes, of heroic stature, who crushed the armies of others.

original: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasinti.🔽Passa puññānaṁ vipākaṁ,🔽Kusalānaṁ sukhesino;
analyzed: saḥ imam pathavim sāgara pariyantam a daṇḍena a satthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasinti 🔽passa puññānam vipāka 🔽kusalānam sukhesinaḥ
translated: I dwelt having conquered this earth to its ocean boundaries without stick or sword, by the law.

original: Mettaṁ cittaṁ vibhāvetvā,
analyzed: mettam cittam vibhāvetvā
translated: Having developed the mind of loving-kindness,

original: Satta vassāni bhikkhavo;
analyzed: satta vassāni bhikkhavo
translated: for seven years, monks,

original: Sattasaṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe,
analyzed: satta sa vaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe
translated: for seven aeons of world-dissolution and evolution,

original: Nayimaṁ lokaṁ punāgamiṁ.
analyzed: nayi imam lokam punar agami
translated: I did not come back to this world.

original: Saṁvaṭṭamāne lokamhi,
analyzed: sa vaṭṭamāne lokamhi
translated: When the world was dissolving,

original: homi ābhassarūpago;
analyzed: homi ābhassarūpago
translated: I went to the Ābhassara (heaven);

original: Vivaṭṭamāne lokasmiṁ,
analyzed: vivaṭṭamāne
translated: When the world was evolving,

original: suññabrahmūpago ahuṁ.
analyzed: ahu
translated: I went to the empty Brahmā (heaven).

original: Sattakkhattuṁ mahābrahmā,
analyzed: sattakkhattum mahābrahmā
translated: For seven times I was the Great Brahmā,

original: vasavattī tadā ahuṁ;
analyzed: vasavattī tadā ahu
translated: and then I was the Vasavattī (god);

original: Chattiṁsakkhattuṁ devindo,🔽devarajjamakārayiṁ.
analyzed: chattisakkhattum devindo  deva rajjam akārayi
translated: For thirty-six times I was the Lord of the Gods,🔽and I ruled as the King of the Gods.

original: Cakkavattī ahuṁ rājā,
analyzed: cakkavattī rājā
translated: I was a King who ruled the world,

original: jambumaṇḍassa issaro;
analyzed: jambumaṇḍassa issaraḥ
translated: the lord of the Rose-Apple Island;

original: Muddhāvasitto khattiyo,
analyzed: muddhāvasittaḥ khattiyaḥ
translated: I was a Khattiya who was anointed,

original: manussādhipatī ahuṁ.
analyzed: ahu
translated: and I was the lord of men.

original: Adaṇḍena asatthena,
analyzed: a daṇḍena a satthena
translated: Without a rod or a sword,

original: vijeyya pathaviṁ imaṁ;
analyzed: vijeyya pathavim ima
translated: I conquered this earth;

original: Asāhasena kammena,
analyzed: asāhasena kammena
translated: Through a deed that was not violent,

original: samena manusāsi taṁ.
analyzed: samena manusā asi ta
translated: I was a just king to the people.

original: Dhammena rajjaṁ kāretvā,
analyzed: dhammena rajjam kāretvā
translated: Having ruled righteously

original: asmiṁ pathavimaṇḍale;
analyzed: asmin pathavi maṇḍale
translated: on this Rose-Apple Island,

original: Mahaddhane mahābhoge,
analyzed: mahat dhane mahā bhoge
translated: I was reborn in a wealthy and prosperous family,

original: aḍḍhe ajāyihaṁ kule.
analyzed: aḍḍhe kule
translated: which was rich and of high standing.

original: Sabbakāmehi sampanne,

translated: An enemy does not delight in an enemy’s wealth.

original: Kodhanassa, bhikkhave, purisapuggalassa kodhābhibhūtassa kodhaparetassa, yepissa
analyzed: kodhanassa bhikkhave purisa puggalassa kodha abhibhūtassa kodha paretassa yepissa
translated: When a person is quick-tempered and overcome by anger, whatever wealth he has

analyzed: te honti bhogāḥ uṭṭhāna vīriya adhigatāḥ bāhā bala paricitā seda avakkhittā dhammikāḥ dhamma laddhā
translated: that has been acquired by exertion, built up by the strength of his arms, earned by the sweat of his brow, righteously gained, and righteously acquired,

original: tepi rājāno rājakosaṁ pavesenti kodhābhibhūtassa.
analyzed: te api rājānaḥ rāja kosam pavesenti kodha abhibhūtassa
translated: and the kings put them in the royal treasury.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, catuttho dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṁ āgacchati itthiṁ vā purisaṁ vā.
analyzed: bhikkhave catutthaḥ dhammo sa patta kantaḥ sa patta karaṇo kodhanam āgacchati itthim vā purisam vā
translated: This is the fourth thing that is unwelcome, disagreeable, and unpleasant to an enemy.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṁ icchati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave sa pattaḥ sa pattassa evam icchati
translated: “Again, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu

original: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa yasavatāya nandati.
analyzed: na bhikkhave sa pattaḥ sa pattassa yasavatāya nandati
translated: An enemy does not delight in an enemy’s fame.

original: Kodhanoyaṁ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto, yopissa so hoti yaso appamādādhigato, tamhāpi dhaṁsati kodhābhibhūto.
analyzed: bhikkhave purisa puggalo kodha abhibhūto kodha pareto yaḥ pissa saḥ hoti yaso appamāda adhigato tamhā api dhasati kodha abhibhūto
translated: When a person is angry and overcome by anger, he destroys any fame he may have gained through heedfulness.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, pañcamo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṁ āgacchati itthiṁ vā purisaṁ vā.
analyzed: bhikkhave pañcamaḥ dhammo sa patta kantaḥ sa patta karaṇo kodhanam āgacchati itthim vā purisam vā
translated: This is the fifth thing that is unwelcome, disagreeable, and unpleasant to an enemy.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṁ icchati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave sa pattaḥ sa pattassa evam icchati
translated: “Again, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

original: ‘aho vatāyaṁ na mittavā assā’ti.
analyzed: aho vata ayam na mittavā assa ati
translated: ‘May he not have friends.’

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa mittavatāya nandati.
analyzed: na bhikkhave sa pattaḥ sa pattassa mittavatāya nandati
translated: An enemy does not delight in an enemy’s friendship.

original: Kodhanaṁ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalaṁ kodhābhibhūtaṁ kodhaparetaṁ, yepissa te honti mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, tepi ārakā parivajjanti kodhābhibhūtaṁ.
analyzed: kodhana bhikkhave purisa puggalam kodha abhibhūtam kodha pareta ye pi ssa te honti mitta amaccāḥ ñāti sālohitā te pi ārakā parivajjanti kodha abhibhūta
translated: When a person is angry and overcome by anger, his friends, companions, relatives, and family members avoid him from afar.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, chaṭṭho dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṁ āgacchati itthiṁ vā purisaṁ vā.
analyzed: bhikkhave chaṭṭhaḥ dhammo sa patta kantaḥ sa patta karaṇo kodhanam āgacchati itthim vā purisam vā
translated: This is the sixth thing gratifying and advantagrous to an enemy that comes upon an angry man or woman.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṁ icchati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave sa pattaḥ sa pattassa evam icchati
translated: “Again, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

original: ‘aho vatāyaṁ kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjeyyā’ti.
analyzed: aho vata ayam kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjeyya ati
translated: ‘May this person, with the breakup of the body, after death, reappear in a state of misery, in a bad destination, in the nether world, in hell!’

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: Why is that?

original: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa sugatigamane nandati.
analyzed: na bhikkhave sa pattaḥ sa pattassa sugati gamane nandati
translated: An enemy does not delight in an enemy’s welfare.

original: Kodhanoyaṁ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: bhikkhave purisa puggalo kodha abhibhūto kodha pareto kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: When a person is angry and overcome by anger, he does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā vācāya …pe…
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam caritvā vācāya pe
translated: Having done so by way of body, speech, and mind,

original: kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati kodhābhibhūto.🔽Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, sattamo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṁ āgacchati itthiṁ vā purisaṁ vā.
analyzed: kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjati kodha abhibhūtaḥ  bhikkhave sattamaḥ dhammo sa patta kantaḥ sa patta karaṇo kodhanam āgacchati itthim vā purisam vā
translated: at the break-up of the body, after death, he reappears in a lower realm, a bad destination, a state of suffering, hell, overwhelmed by anger.🔽This is the seventh thing gratifying and advantagous to an enemy that comes upon an angry man or woman.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, satta dhammā sapattakantā sapattakaraṇā kodhanaṁ āgacchanti itthiṁ vā purisaṁ vāti.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave satta dhammā sa patta kantā sa patta karaṇā kodhanam āgacchanti itthim vā purisam vā ati

original: 7. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Division

original: Hirīottappasutta
analyzed: hirīottappa sutta
translated: Conscience and Shame

original: “Hirottappe, bhikkhave, asati hirottappavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti indriyasaṁvaro;🔽indriyasaṁvare asati indriyasaṁvaravipannassa hatūpanisaṁ hoti sīlaṁ;
analyzed: hirottappe bhikkhave asati hirottappa vipannassa hatu upanisaḥ hoti indriya savaraḥ  indriya savare asati indriya savara vipannassa hatūpanisam hoti sīla
translated: “When there is no conscience and shame, monks, there is failure in conscience and shame. When there is failure in conscience and shame, there is failure in restraint of the faculties.

original: sīle asati sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;🔽sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṁ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṁ;
analyzed: sīle asati sīla vipannassa hatu upanisaḥ hoti sammāsamādhi  sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhi vipannassa hatūpanisam hoti yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassana
translated: When there is failure in restraint of the faculties, there is failure in virtue. When there is failure in virtue, there is failure in right concentration.

original: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
analyzed: yathābhūta ñāṇa dassane asati yathābhūta ñāṇa dassana vipannassa hatu upanisaḥ hoti nibbidā virāgo
translated: When there is failure in right concentration, there is failure in the knowledge and vision of things as they really are. When there is failure in the knowledge and vision of things as they really are, there is failure in disenchantment and dispassion.

original: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṁ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṁ.
analyzed: nibbidā virāge asati nibbidā virāga vipannassa hatūpanisam hoti vimutti ñāṇa dassana
translated: When there is failure in disenchantment and dispassion, there is failure in the knowledge and vision of liberation.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsavipanno.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave rukkhaḥ sākhā palāsa vipannaḥ
translated: “Suppose there were a tree without branches and foliage.

original: Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṁ gacchati, tacopi pheggupi sāropi na pāripūriṁ gacchati.
analyzed: tassa papaṭikā api na pāripūrim gacchati tacaḥ api pheggu api sāraḥ api na pāripūrim gacchati
translated: Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, hirottappe asati hirottappavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti indriyasaṁvaro;
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave hirottappe asati hirottappa vipannassa hatu upanisaḥ hoti indriya savaraḥ
translated: So too, when there is no conscience and shame, there is failure in conscience and shame.

original: indriyasaṁvare asati indriyasaṁvaravipannassa hatūpanisaṁ hoti sīlaṁ;🔽sīle asati sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
analyzed: indriya savare asati indriya savara vipannassa hatūpanisam hoti sīla  sīle asati sīla vipannassa hatu upanisaḥ hoti sammāsamādhi
translated: When there is no restraint of the faculties, failure in restraint of the faculties, one’s virtue is undermined.🔽When there is no virtue, failure in virtue, one’s concentration is undermined.

original: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṁ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṁ;🔽yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
analyzed: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhi vipannassa hatūpanisam hoti yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassana  yathābhūta ñāṇa dassane asati yathābhūta ñāṇa dassana vipannassa hatu upanisaḥ hoti nibbidā virāgo
translated: When there is no concentration, failure in concentration, one’s wisdom is undermined.🔽When there is no wisdom, failure in wisdom, one’s knowledge and vision of things as they really are is undermined.🔽When there is no knowledge and vision of things as they really are, failure in knowledge and vision of things as they really are, one’s disenchantment and dispassion is undermined.

original: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṁ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṁ.
analyzed: nibbidā virāge asati nibbidā virāga vipannassa hatūpanisam hoti vimutti ñāṇa dassana
translated: When there is no disenchantment and dispassion, failure in disenchantment and dispassion, one’s knowledge and vision of liberation is undermined.

original: Hirottappe, bhikkhave, sati hirottappasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti indriyasaṁvaro;🔽indriyasaṁvare sati indriyasaṁvarasampannassa upanisasampannaṁ hoti sīlaṁ;🔽sīle sati sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
analyzed: hirottappe bhikkhave sati hirottappa sampannassa upanisa sampannaḥ hoti indriya savaraḥ  indriya savare sati indriya savara sampannassa upanisa sampannam hoti sīla  sīle sati sīla sampannassa upanisa sampannaḥ hoti sammāsamādhi
translated: When there is conscience and shame, one who possesses conscience and shame has the support of the restraint of the faculties.🔽When there is the restraint of the faculties, one who possesses the restraint of the faculties has the support of virtue.🔽When there is virtue, one who possesses virtue has the support of concentration.

original: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṁ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṁ;
analyzed: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhi sampannassa upanisa sampannam hoti yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassana
translated: When there is concentration, one who possesses concentration has the support of knowledge and vision of things as they really are.

original: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
analyzed: yathābhūta ñāṇa dassane sati yathābhūta ñāṇa dassana sampannassa upanisa sampannaḥ hoti nibbidā virāgo
translated: When there’s knowledge and vision of things as they really are, one who has knowledge and vision of things as they really are possesses the requisite of disenchantment and dispassion.

original: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṁ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṁ.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṁ gacchati, tacopi pheggupi sāropi pāripūriṁ gacchati.
analyzed: nibbidā virāge sati nibbidā virāga sampannassa upanisa sampannam hoti vimutti ñāṇa dassana  seyyathā api bhikkhave rukkhaḥ sākhā palāsa sampannaḥ tassa papaṭikā api pāripūrim gacchati tacaḥ api pheggu api sāraḥ api pāripūrim gacchati
translated: When there’s disenchantment and dispassion, one who has disenchantment and dispassion possesses the requisite of knowledge and vision of freedom.🔽“Suppose a tree was rich in sap, heartwood, and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and sapwood would be well developed.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, hirottappe sati hirottappasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti …pe…
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave hirottappe sati hirottappa sampannassa upanisa sampannaḥ hoti pe
translated: In the same way, when there’s conscience and prudence, one who has conscience and prudence possesses the requisite of knowledge and vision of things as they really are …

original: vimuttiñāṇadassanan”ti.🔽Paṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: vimutti ñāṇa dassananti  paṭhama
translated: knowledge and vision of freedom.”🔽The first section for recitation on the requisites is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 7.66
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of Elevens

original: 7. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Great Chapter

original: Sattasūriyasutta
analyzed: sattasūriyasutta
translated: Seven Suns

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: This is what I have heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā vesāliyaṁ viharati ambapālivane.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā vesāliyam viharati ambapāli vane
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Vesālī in the hall with the peaked roof in Ambapālī’s Wood.

original: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There he addressed the monks:

original: “bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Monks!”

original: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said this:

original: “Aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā;🔽adhuvā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā;
analyzed: aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ  adhuvā bhikkhave saṅkhārā
translated: “Monks, conditioned phenomena are impermanent,🔽unstable, and unreliable.

original: anassāsikā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā.
analyzed: an assāsikāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ
translated: Monks, conditioned phenomena are subject to change.

original: Yāvañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṁ alaṁ virajjituṁ alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: yāvat cita bhikkhave alam eva sabba saṅkhāresu nibbinditum alam virajjitum alam vimuccitu
translated: Therefore, monks, you should be disenchanted with all conditioned phenomena, be dispassionate toward them, and overcome them.

original: Sineru, bhikkhave, pabbatarājā caturāsītiyojanasahassāni āyāmena, caturāsītiyojanasahassāni
analyzed: sineru bhikkhave pabbata rājā caturāsīti yojana sahassāni āyāmena caturāsīti yojana sahassāni
translated: “Monks, the king of mountains, Mount Sineru, is eighty-four thousand leagues long from east to west, and eighty-four thousand leagues wide from north to south.🔽It extends eighty-four thousand leagues down into the earth,

original: vitthārena, caturāsītiyojanasahassāni mahāsamudde ajjhogāḷho, caturāsītiyojanasahassāni🔽mahāsamuddā accuggato.
analyzed: vitthārena catur asīti yojana sahassāni mahā samudde ajjhogāḷhaḥ catur asīti yojana sahassāni  mahā samuddā accuggataḥ
translated: and it rises eighty-four thousand leagues above the earth.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni devo na vassati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassa satāni bahūni vassa sahassāni bahūni vassa sata sahassāni devaḥ na vassati
translated: “Monks, there comes a time when, after a very long period, the sun and moon rise in the world.

original: Deve kho pana, bhikkhave, avassante ye kecime bījagāmabhūtagāmā osadhitiṇavanappatayo te ussussanti visussanti, na bhavanti.
analyzed: deve kho pana bhikkhave a vassante ye keci ime bīja gāma bhūta gāmāḥ osadhi tiṇa vana ppatayo te ussussanti visussanti na bhavanti
translated: When the sun and moon have risen, the seeds, sprouts, and seedlings that grow in the water dry up and disappear.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā;🔽evaṁ adhuvā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā …pe…
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ  evam adhuvā bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ pe
translated: so impermanent are formations, bhikkhus,

original: alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: alam vimuccitu
translated: enough to be disgusted with all formations, enough to be detached from all formations, enough to be released from all formations.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena dutiyo sūriyo pātubhavati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena dutiyaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: “There comes a time, bhikkhus, sooner or later after a long period, when a second sun appears in the world.

original: Dutiyassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā yā kāci kunnadiyo kusobbhā tā ussussanti visussanti, na bhavanti.
analyzed: dutiyassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā yā kāci kunnadiyaḥ kusobbhā tāḥ ussussanti visussanti na bhavanti
translated: With the appearance of the second sun, whatever small rivers there are flow dry and disappear.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā …pe…
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ pe
translated: So impermanent are formations, bhikkhus,

original: alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: alam vimuccitu
translated: enough to be disgusted with all formations, enough to be detached from all formations, enough to be released from all formations.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena tatiyo sūriyo pātubhavati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena tatiyaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: “There comes a time, bhikkhus, sooner or later after a long period, when a third sun appears in the world.

original: Tatiyassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā yā kāci mahānadiyo, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: tatiyassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā yā kāci
translated: With the appearance of the third sun, whatever great rivers there are—

original: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, tā ussussanti visussanti, na bhavanti.
analyzed: gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū mahī tāḥ ussussanti visussanti na bhavanti
translated: the Ganges, the Yamunā, the Aciravatī, the Sarabhū, and the Mahī—flow dry and disappear.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā …pe…
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ pe
translated: So impermanent are formations, bhikkhus,

original: alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: alam vimuccitu
translated: enough to be disgusted with all formations, enough to be detached from all formations, enough to be released from all formations.🔽“There comes a time, bhikkhus, sooner or later after a long period,

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena catuttho sūriyo pātubhavati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena catutthaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: There comes a time, monks, when after a long period of time a fourth sun appears.

original: Catutthassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā ye te mahāsarā yato imā mahānadiyo pavattanti, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: catutthassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā ye te mahā sarāḥ yatas imāḥ mahā nadiyaḥ pavattanti
translated: With the appearance of the fourth sun, the great lakes from which these great rivers flow —

original: anotattā, sīhapapātā, rathakārā, kaṇṇamuṇḍā, kuṇālā, chaddantā, mandākiniyā, tā ussussanti visussanti, na bhavanti.
analyzed: anotattā sīhapapātā rathakārā kaṇṇamuṇḍā kuṇālā chaddantā mandākiniyā tāḥ ussussanti visussanti na bhavanti
translated: the Lake Anotatta, the Lake Sihapapata, the Lake Rathakara, the Lake Kannamunda, the Lake Kuna, the Lake Chaddanta, the Lake Mandakini — dry up and disappear.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā …pe…
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ pe
translated: So impermanent are formations, monks, so unstable, so unreliable.

original: alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: alam vimuccitu
translated: Enough, monks, with sensual pleasures.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena pañcamo sūriyo pātubhavati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena pañcamaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: There comes a time, monks, when after a long period of time a fifth sun appears.

original: Pañcamassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā yojanasatikānipi mahāsamudde udakāni ogacchanti,
analyzed: pañcamassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā yojana satikāni pi mahā samudde udakāni ogacchanti
translated: With the appearance of the fifth sun, the ocean water decreases by a hundred leagues.

original: dviyojanasatikānipi mahāsamudde udakāni ogacchanti, tiyojanasatikānipi, catuyojanasatikānipi,
analyzed: dvi yojana satikāni api mahā samudde udakāni ogacchanti ti yojana satikāni api catu yojana satikāni api
translated: Then by two hundred leagues,

original: pañcayojanasatikānipi, chayojanasatikānipi, sattayojanasatikānipi mahāsamudde udakāni ogacchanti;
analyzed: pañca yojana satikāni api cha yojana satikāni api satta yojana satikāni api mahā samudde udakāni ogacchanti
translated: and the water in the ocean sinks down five hundred leagues, six hundred leagues, seven hundred leagues.

original: sattatālampi mahāsamudde udakaṁ saṇṭhāti, chatālampi, pañcatālampi, catutālampi, titālampi, dvitālampi, tālamattampi mahāsamudde udakaṁ saṇṭhāti;
analyzed: satta tālampi mahā samudde udakam saṇṭhāti cha tālampi pañca tālampi catu tālampi ti tālampi dvi tālampi tāla mattampi mahā samudde udakam saṇṭhāti
translated: The water in the ocean stands having sunk down seven fathoms, six, five, four, three, two, one fathom, or it stands having sunk down even less than that.

original: sattaporisampi mahāsamudde udakaṁ saṇṭhāti, chaporisampi, pañcaporisampi, catuporisampi,
analyzed: satta porisam pi mahā samudde udakam saṇṭhāti cha porisam pi pañca porisam pi catu porisam pi
translated: The water in the ocean stands having sunk down seven times, six times, five times, four times,

original: tiporisampi, dviporisampi, porisampi, aḍḍhaporisampi, kaṭimattampi, jaṇṇukāmattampi,🔽gopphakamattampi mahāsamudde udakaṁ saṇṭhāti.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, saradasamaye thullaphusitake deve vassante tattha tattha gopadesu udakāni ṭhitāni honti;
analyzed: ti porisampi dvi porisampi porisampi aḍḍha porisampi kaṭi mattampi jaṇṇukā mattampi  gopphaka mattam api mahā samudde udakam saṇṭhāti  seyyathā api bhikkhave sarada samaye thullaphusitake deve vassante tattha tattha gopadesu udakāni ṭhitāni honti
translated: three times, twice, once, half a time, or it stands having sunk down even less than that.🔽Just as, when the sky is overcast with clouds and it is raining heavily, the water stands on the higher ground in ponds and lakes,

original: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tattha tattha gopphakamattāni mahāsamudde udakāni ṭhitāni honti.
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave tattha tattha gopphaka mattāni mahā samudde udakāni ṭhitāni honti
translated: so too, the water in the ocean stands in places having sunk down only as much as the ankle, the knee, or the thigh.

original: Pañcamassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā aṅgulipabbamattampi mahāsamudde udakaṁ na hoti.
analyzed: pañcamassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā aṅguli pabba mattam pi mahā samudde udakam na hoti
translated: With the appearance of the fifth sun, there is not even that much water left in the great ocean as would wet one’s fingernail.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā …pe…
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ pe
translated: So impermanent are formations, bhikkhus…

original: alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: alam vimuccitu
translated: enough to be liberated from them.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena chaṭṭho sūriyo pātubhavati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena chaṭṭhaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: “There comes a time, bhikkhus, sooner or later after a long period, when a sixth sun appears.

original: Chaṭṭhassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā ayañca mahāpathavī sineru ca pabbatarājā dhūmāyanti sandhūmāyanti sampadhūmāyanti.
analyzed: chaṭṭhassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā ayam ca mahā pathavī sineru ca pabbata rājā dhūmāyanti sandhūmāyanti sampadhūmāyanti
translated: With the appearance of the sixth sun, this great earth with its mountains and forests would blaze up and be consumed by fire.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbhakārapāko ālepito paṭhamaṁ dhūmeti sandhūmeti sampadhūmeti;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave kumbhakāra pākaḥ ālepitaḥ paṭhamam dhūmeti sandhūmeti sampadhūmeti
translated: Just as when a smith’s furnace is burning, blazing and aflame, a small spark blown by the wind would blaze up, burn, and be extinguished;

original: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, chaṭṭhassa sūriyassa pātubhāvā ayañca mahāpathavī sineru ca pabbatarājā dhūmāyanti sandhūmāyanti sampadhūmāyanti.
analyzed: evam evam kho bhikkhave chaṭṭhassa sūriyassa pātubhāvāḥ ayañca mahā pathavī sineru ca pabbata rājā dhūmāyanti sandhūmāyanti sampadhūmāyanti
translated: so too, with the appearance of the sixth sun, this great earth with its mountains and forests would blaze up and be consumed by fire.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā …pe…
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ pe
translated: So impermanent are formations, bhikkhus…

original: alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
analyzed: alam vimuccitu
translated: enough to be liberated from them.🔽“There comes a time, bhikkhus, sooner or later after a long period, when a seventh sun appears.

original: Hoti kho so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena sattamo sūriyo pātubhavati.
analyzed: hoti kho saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena sattamaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: There comes a time, monks, when after a long period of time a seventh sun appears.

original: Sattamassa, bhikkhave, sūriyassa pātubhāvā ayañca mahāpathavī sineru ca pabbatarājā ādippanti pajjalanti ekajālā bhavanti.
analyzed: sattamassa bhikkhave sūriyassa pātubhāvā ayañca mahā pathavī sineru ca pabbata rājā ādippanti pajjalanti eka jālāḥ bhavanti
translated: With the appearance of the seventh sun, this great earth with its mountains and forests catches fire,

original: Imissā ca, bhikkhave, mahāpathaviyā sinerussa ca pabbatarājassa jhāyamānānaṁ dayhamānānaṁ acci vātena khittā yāva brahmalokāpi gacchati.
analyzed: imissā ca bhikkhave mahā pathaviyā sinerussa ca pabbata rājassa jhāyamānānam dayhamānānam acci vātena khittā yāva brahma lokā api gacchati
translated: and the flame, driven by the wind, rises as far as the Brahma world.

original: Sinerussa, bhikkhave, pabbatarājassa jhāyamānassa dayhamānassa vinassamānassa mahatā🔽tejokhandhena abhibhūtassa yojanasatikānipi kūṭāni palujjanti dviyojanasatikānipi,
analyzed: sinerussa bhikkhave pabbata rājassa jhāyamānassa dayhamānassa vinassamānassa mahatā  tejaḥ khandhena abhibhūtassa yojana satikāni api kūṭāni palujjanti dvi yojana satikāni api
translated: When the great mountain Sineru is burning, monks, and being consumed,🔽the peaks a hundred leagues high collapse,

original: tiyojanasatikānipi, catuyojanasatikānipi, pañcayojanasatikānipi kūṭāni palujjanti.
analyzed: ti yojana satikāni api catur yojana satikāni api pañca yojana satikāni api kūṭāni palujjanti
translated: the peaks two, three, four, five hundred leagues high collapse.

original: Imissā ca, bhikkhave, mahāpathaviyā sinerussa ca pabbatarājassa jhāyamānānaṁ dayhamānānaṁ neva chārikā paññāyati na masi.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa dayhamānassa neva chārikā paññāyati na masi;🔽evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, imissā ca mahāpathaviyā sinerussa ca pabbatarājassa jhāyamānānaṁ dayhamānānaṁ neva chārikā paññāyati na masi.
analyzed: imissā ca bhikkhave mahā pathaviyā sinerussa ca pabbatarājassa jhāyamānānam dayhamānānam na iva chārikā paññāyati na masi  seyyathā api bhikkhave sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa dayhamānassa na iva chārikā paññāyati na masi  evam evam kho bhikkhave imissā ca mahā pathaviyā sinerussa ca pabbata rājassa jhāyamānānam dayhamānānam na iva chārikā paññāyati na masi
translated: And when this great earth and Sineru, the king of mountains, are burning and blazing, there is no ash or soot to be seen.🔽Just as when ghee or oil is burning and blazing, there is no ash or soot to be seen;🔽so too, when this great earth and Sineru, the king of mountains, are burning and blazing, there is no ash or soot to be seen.

original: Evaṁ aniccā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā;🔽evaṁ adhuvā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā;🔽evaṁ anassāsikā, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā.🔽Yāvañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṁ alaṁ virajjituṁ alaṁ vimuccituṁ.🔽Tatra, bhikkhave, ko mantā ko saddhātā:
analyzed: evam aniccāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ 🔽evam adhuvāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ 🔽evam an assāsikāḥ bhikkhave saṅkhārāḥ 🔽yāvat cita bhikkhave alam eva sabba saṅkhāresu nibbinditum alam virajjitum alam vimuccitu 🔽tatra bhikkhave kaḥ mantā kaḥ saddhātā
translated: And when this great earth and Sineru, the king of mountains, are burning, not even ashes or dust can be found.

original: ‘ayañca pathavī sineru ca pabbatarājā dayhissanti vinassissanti, na bhavissantī’ti aññatra diṭṭhapadehi?
analyzed: ayam ca pathavī sineru ca pabbata rājā dayhissanti vinassissanti na bhavissanti iti aññatra diṭṭhapadehi
translated: ‘This earth and the Sineru, king of mountains, will burn and vanish, and will no longer be!’

original: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, sunetto nāma satthā ahosi titthakaro kāmesu vītarāgo.
analyzed: bhūta pubba bhikkhave sunettaḥ nāma satthā ahosi titthakaraḥ kāmesu vīta rāgaḥ
translated: Once, monks, there was a teacher called Sunetta, a sectarian leader who was free from lust.

original: Sunettassa kho pana, bhikkhave, satthuno anekāni sāvakasatāni ahesuṁ.
analyzed: sunettassa kho pana bhikkhave satthunaḥ anekāni sāvaka satāni ahesu
translated: Sunetta had many hundreds of pupils.

original: Sunetto, bhikkhave, satthā sāvakānaṁ brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṁ desesi.🔽Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, sunettassa satthuno brahmalokasahabyatāya dhammaṁ desentassa sabbena sabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājāniṁsu te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ brahmalokaṁ upapajjiṁsu.🔽Ye na sabbena sabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājāniṁsu te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā appekacce paranimmitavasavattīnaṁ
analyzed: sunettaḥ bhikkhave satthā sāvakānam brahma loka sahabya tāya dhammaṃ desesi  ye kho pana bhikkhave sunettassa satthuno brahma loka sahabya tāya dhammam desentassa sabbena sabbam sāsanam ājānisu te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim brahma lokam upapajjisu  ye na sabbena sabbam sāsanam ājānisu te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā appa ekacce
translated: Sunetta taught his pupils the Dhamma for companionship with the Brahma-world.🔽Those of Sunetta’s pupils who completely understood the Teacher’s instruction, at the break-up of the body, after death, arose in the company of the Brahma-world.

original: devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu, appekacce nimmānaratīnaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu,
analyzed: devānam sahabyatam upapajjisu appekacce nimmānaratīnam devānam sahabyatam upapajjisu
translated: Those of Sunetta’s pupils who did not completely understand the Teacher’s instruction, at the break-up of the body, after death, some arose in the company of the gods who delight in creation, some arose in the company of the gods who control the creations of others,

original: appekacce tusitānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu, appekacce yāmānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ
analyzed: appa ekacce tusitānam devānam sahabyatam upapajjisu appa ekacce yāmānam devānam sahabyata
translated: some were reborn in the company of the Tusita gods, some in the company of the Yāma gods,🔽some in the company of the gods who delight in creation, some in the company of the gods who control what is created by others,

original: upapajjiṁsu, appekacce tāvatiṁsānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu, appekacce cātumahārājikānaṁ🔽devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu, appekacce khattiyamahāsālānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu,🔽appekacce brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu, appekacce gahapatimahāsālānaṁ
analyzed: upapajjisu appa ekacce tāvatisānam devānam sahabyatam upapajjisu appa ekacce cātumahārājikānam  devānam sahabyatam upapajjisu appekacce khattiya mahāsālānam sahabyatam upapajjisu  appekacce brāhmaṇa mahā sālānam sahabyatam upapajjisu appekacce gahapati mahā sālānam
translated: some in the company of the gods of the Thirty-three, some in the company of the gods of the Four Great Kings,🔽some in the company of the aristocrats,

original: sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu.
analyzed: upapajjisu
translated: some in the company of the brahmins, some in the company of the householders.

original: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sunettassa satthuno etadahosi:
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave sunettassa satthuno etat ahosi
translated: Then the teacher Sunetta thought:

original: ‘na kho metaṁ patirūpaṁ yohaṁ sāvakānaṁ samasamagatiyo assaṁ abhisamparāyaṁ, yannūnāhaṁ uttari mettaṁ bhāveyyan’ti.
analyzed: na kho mā etam patirūpam yaḥ ham sāvakānam sama sama gatiyaḥ assam abhisamparāya yat nūna aham uttari mā ittam bhāveyyanti
translated: ‘It is not right that I should have the same destiny as my disciples in the next life. Let me develop loving-kindness further.’

original: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sunetto satthā satta vassāni mettaṁ cittaṁ bhāvesi.
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave sunettaḥ satthā satta vassāni mettam cittam bhāvesi
translated: So for seven years the teacher Sunetta developed loving-kindness.

original: Satta vassāni mettaṁ cittaṁ bhāvetvā satta saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe nayimaṁ lokaṁ punarāgamāsi.🔽Saṁvaṭṭamāne sudaṁ, bhikkhave, loke ābhassarūpago hoti.
analyzed: satta vassāni mettam cittam bhāvetvā satta sa vaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe nayimam lokam punar āgamāsi  sa vaṭṭamāne suda bhikkhave loke ābhassa rūpago hoti
translated: When the world dissolved, he went to the Ābhassara plane,

original: Vivaṭṭamāne loke suññaṁ brahmavimānaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: vivaṭṭamāne loke suññam brahmavimānam upapajjati
translated: and when the world evolved, he was reborn in an empty divine mansion.

original: Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, brahmā hoti mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī.
analyzed: tatra suda bhikkhave brahmā hoti mahābrahmā abhibhū an abhibhūtaḥ vasavattī
translated: There he became Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undisputed, the Powerful, the Controller, the Alcreator, the Ordainer, the Father of All That Are and Are to Be, the Ruler, Lord over All.

original: Chattiṁsakkhattuṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, sakko ahosi devānamindo.
analyzed: chattisa khattum kho pana bhikkhave sakkaḥ ahosi devānamindo
translated: Thirty-six times he was Sakka, ruler of the gods,

original: Anekasatakkhattuṁ rājā ahosi cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
analyzed: aneka sata kkhattum rājā ahosi cakkavattī dhammikaḥ dhamma rājā cāturantaḥ vijitāvī janapadatthāvariya ppatto satta ratana samannāgato
translated: and many hundreds of times he was a wealthy and powerful king.

original: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā ahesuṁ sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
analyzed: parosahassam kho panassa puttāḥ ahesum sūrāḥ vīraṅga rūpāḥ para sena pamaddanāḥ
translated: He had more than a thousand sons who were heroes, of heroic stature, conquerors of the hostile army.

original: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasi.
analyzed: saḥ imam pathavim sāgara pariyantam a daṇḍena a satthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasi
translated: He ruled this earth as far as its ocean boundaries, without stick or sword, by the Dhamma.

original: So hi nāma, bhikkhave, sunetto satthā evaṁ dīghāyuko samāno evaṁ ciraṭṭhitiko aparimutto ahosi:
analyzed: saḥ hi nāma bhikkhave sunettaḥ satthā evam dīgha āyukaḥ samānaḥ evam cira ṭṭhitikaḥ a parimuttaḥ ahosi
translated: And yet, monks, that teacher Sunetta, though he lived so long, so far from being released from birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair, was not even released from the suffering of the hells.

original: ‘jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, aparimutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
analyzed: jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi a parimuttaḥ dukkhasma ati vadāmi
translated: I say that he was not released from suffering.

original: Taṁ kissa hetu?
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu
translated: And why not?

original: Catunnaṁ dhammānaṁ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā.
analyzed: catunnam dhammānam an anubodhā appaṭivedhā
translated: Because of not knowing and not seeing four things.

original: Katamesaṁ catunnaṁ?
analyzed: katamesam
translated: What four?

original: Ariyassa, bhikkhave, sīlassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā, ariyassa samādhissa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā, ariyāya paññāya ananubodhā appaṭivedhā, ariyāya vimuttiyā ananubodhā appaṭivedhā.🔽Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ sīlaṁ anubuddhaṁ paṭividdhaṁ, ariyo samādhi anubodho paṭividdho,
analyzed: ariyassa bhikkhave sīlassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā ariyassa samādhissa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā ariyāya paññāya ananubodhā appaṭivedhā ariyāya vimuttiyāḥ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā  bhikkhave ariyam sīlam anubuddham paṭividdha ariyaḥ samādhi anubodhaḥ paṭividdhaḥ
translated: The noble virtue, monks, was not known or seen; the noble concentration was not known or seen; the noble wisdom was not known or seen; the noble release was not known or seen.🔽But, monks, the noble virtue has been known and seen; the noble concentration has been known and seen;

original: ariyā paññā anubodhā paṭividdhā, ariyā vimutti anubodhā paṭividdhā, ucchinnā bhavataṇhā,
analyzed: ariyā paññā anubodhā paṭividdhā ariyā vimutti anubodhā paṭividdhā ucchinnā bhava taṇhā
translated: the noble wisdom has been known and seen; the noble release has been known and seen. Craving for existence has been cut off;

original: khīṇā bhavanetti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
analyzed: khīṇā bhavanā itti natthi dāni punabbhavaḥ ti
translated: the conduit to existence has been destroyed; now there is no continuation of existence.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
analyzed: idam vatvāna sugataḥ atha aparam etat avoca satthā
translated: The One of Broad Wisdom, having said this, went on to say this:

original: “Sīlaṁ samādhi paññā ca,
analyzed: sīlam samādhi paññā ca
translated: “Virtue, concentration, and wisdom,

original: vimutti ca anuttarā;
analyzed: vimutti ca anuttarā
translated: and unsurpassed freedom:

original: Anubuddhā ime dhammā,
analyzed: anubuddhāḥ ime dhammā
translated: These ideas have been awakened to

original: gotamena yasassinā.
analyzed: gotamena yasassinā
translated: by Gotama, the one with fame.

original: Iti buddho abhiññāya,
analyzed: iti buddhaḥ abhiññāya
translated: Thus the Buddha, having directly known,

original: dhammamakkhāsi bhikkhunaṁ;
analyzed: dhammam akkhāsi bhikkhuna
translated: proclaimed this teaching to the monks:

original: Dukkhassantakaro satthā,
analyzed: satthā
translated: The Teacher, the one who has made an end of suffering,

original: cakkhumā parinibbuto”ti.
analyzed: cakkhumā parinibbuto ti
translated: the one with vision, is fully extinguished.”

original: Dutiyaṁ.
analyzed: dutiya
translated: The second section.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 7.67
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Tens

original: 7. Mahāvagga
analyzed: mahāvagga
translated: The Greater Section

original: Nagaropamasutta
analyzed: nagaropamasutta
translated: The Simile of the City

original: “Yato kho, bhikkhave, rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ sattahi nagaraparikkhārehi suparikkhataṁ hoti, catunnañca āhārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantimam nagaram sattahi nagara parikkhārehi su parikkhatam hoti catunnam ca āhārānam nikāma lābhī hoti akiccha lābhī akasira lābhī
translated: “Bhikkhus, when a king’s border city is well fortified with sevenfold protection and obtains timely food, it is called a king’s border city that cannot be assailed by external foes and enemies.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ akaraṇīyaṁ bāhirehi paccatthikehi paccāmittehi.
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantimam nagaram a karaṇīyam bāhirehi paccatthikehi pacca amittehi
translated: This is called a king’s border city that cannot be assailed by external foes and enemies.

original: Katamehi sattahi nagaraparikkhārehi suparikkhataṁ hoti?
analyzed: katamehi sattahi nagara parikkhārehi su parikkhatam hoti
translated: What are the sevenfold protections with which it is well fortified?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare esikā hoti gambhīranemā sunikhātā acalā asampavedhī.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantime nagare esikā hoti gambhīra nemā su nikhātā acalā a sampavedhī
translated: There is a moat that is deep and wide.

original: Iminā paṭhamena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: iminā paṭhamena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti rañño paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: With this first requisite, the king’s border town is well fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those without.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare parikkhā hoti gambhīrā ceva vitthatā ca.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare parikkhā hoti gambhīrā ca iva vitthatā ca
translated: Again, there is a trench that is deep and wide.

original: Iminā dutiyena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: iminā dutiyena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti rañño paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: With this second requisite, the king’s border town is well fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those without.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare anupariyāyapatho hoti ucco ceva vitthato ca.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare anupariyāya pathaḥ hoti uccaḥ ca iva vitthataḥ ca
translated: Again, there is a highway that is high and wide.

original: Iminā tatiyena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: iminā tatiyena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti rañño paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: With this third requisite, the king’s border town is well fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those without.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ āvudhaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti salākañceva jevanikañca.
analyzed: punar capara bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantime nagare bahum āvudham sannicitam hoti salākam ca iva jevanikam ca
translated: “Again, in the king’s border town there is a great store of grass, timber, & water.

original: Iminā catutthena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahubalakāyo paṭivasati, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: iminā catutthena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti rañño paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya  puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare bahu balakāyaḥ paṭivasati
translated: With this fourth requisite, the king’s border town is well-fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those outside.

original: hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsakaputtā.
analyzed: hattha ārohāḥ assa ārohāḥ rathikāḥ dhanuggahāḥ celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakāḥ uggāḥ rāja puttā pakkhandinaḥ mahā nāgā sūrā camma yodhinaḥ dāsaka puttā
translated: “Again, in the king’s border town there dwells a large army—elephant troops, cavalry, charioteers, & footsoldiers.

original: Iminā pañcamena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: iminā pañcamena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti rañño paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: With this fifth requisite, the king’s border town is well-fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those outside.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare dovāriko hoti paṇḍito byatto medhāvī aññātānaṁ nivāretā ñātānaṁ pavesetā.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare dovārikaḥ hoti paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ medhāvī aññātānam nivāretā ñātānam pavesetā
translated: “Again, in the king’s border town there is a gatekeeper—wise, experienced, intelligent—who keeps out strangers and lets in acquaintances.

original: Iminā chaṭṭhena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: iminā chaṭṭhena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti raññaḥ paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: With this sixth requisite of a fortified city, the king’s frontier city is well fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those outside.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare pākāro hoti ucco ceva vitthato ca vāsanalepanasampanno ca.🔽Iminā sattamena nagaraparikkhārena suparikkhataṁ hoti rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ abbhantarānaṁ guttiyā bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare pākāraḥ hoti uccaḥ ca iva vitthataḥ ca vāsana lepana sampanno ca  iminā sattamena nagara parikkhārena su parikkhatam hoti rañño paccantimam nagaram abbhantarānam guttiyā bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: “Again, the king’s frontier city is provided with an outer wall high and strong, with strong corner towers and a strong gateway.🔽With this seventh requisite of a fortified city, the king’s frontier city is well fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those outside.

original: Imehi sattahi nagaraparikkhārehi suparikkhataṁ hoti.🔽Katamesaṁ catunnaṁ āhārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī?
analyzed: imehi sattahi nagara parikkhārehi su parikkhatam hoti  katamesam catunnam āhārānam nikāma lābhī hoti a kiccha lābhī a kasira lābhī
translated: With these seven requisites of a fortified city, that king’s frontier city is well fortified for the protection of those within and the exclusion of those outside.🔽“With the attainment of four kinds of expression, the Tathāgata is called one of great wisdom.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantime nagare bahum tiṇa kaṭṭha udakam sannicitam hoti abbhantarānam ratiyā a paritassāya phāsu vihārāya bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: “Here, in the king’s frontier city, much timber, firewood, water, and grass are stored for the enjoyment of those within, for their ease and comfort, and to ward off external foes.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ sāliyavakaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ tilamuggamāsāparaṇṇaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare bahum sāli yavakam sannicitam hoti abbhantarānam ratiyā a paritassāya phāsu vihārāya bāhirānam paṭighātāya  puna capara bhikkhave rañño paccantime nagare bahum tila mugga māsa aparaṇṇam sannicitam hoti abbhantarānam ratiyā a paritassāya phāsu vihārāya bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: “Again, in a well-fortified city, there is a great deal of rice and barley stored for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of those within and to ward off those without.🔽“Again, in a well-fortified city, there is a great deal of sesame, green gram, and kidney beans stored for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of those within and to ward off those without.🔽

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ bhesajjaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantime nagare bahum bhesajjam sannicitam hoti
translated: “Again, in the king’s border fortress there is a great store of rice and curry🔽and a great store of sakkara and oil,

original: sappi navanītaṁ telaṁ madhu phāṇitaṁ loṇaṁ abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.
analyzed: sappi navanītam telam madhu phāṇitam loṇam abbhantarānam ratiyā a paritassāya phāsu vihārāya bāhirānam paṭighātāya
translated: and a great store of medicine—ghee, fresh butter, oil, honey, sugar, and salt—🔽for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of those within and to ward off those without.

original: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṁ āhārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
analyzed: imesam kho bhikkhave catunnam āhārānam nikāma lābhī hoti akiccha lābhī akasira lābhī
translated: He obtains these four kinds of nutriment without difficulty, without trouble, and without hindrance.

original: Yato kho, bhikkhave, rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ imehi sattahi nagaraparikkhārehi suparikkhataṁ hoti, imesañca catunnaṁ āhārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
analyzed: yatas kho bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantimam nagaram imehi sattahi nagara parikkhārehi su parikkhatam hoti imesam ca catunnam āhārānam nikāma lābhī hoti akiccha lābhī akasira lābhī
translated: When a king’s border town is well-fortified with these seven kinds of fortifications and has easy access to these four kinds of provisions,

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, rañño paccantimaṁ nagaraṁ akaraṇīyaṁ bāhirehi paccatthikehi paccāmittehi.🔽Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, yato ariyasāvako sattahi saddhammehi samannāgato hoti, catunnañca
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantimam nagaram a karaṇīyam bāhirehi paccatthikehi pacca amittehi  evam evam kho bhikkhave yatas ariya sāvako sattahi saddhammehi samannāgataḥ hoti catunnam ca
translated: it is called a town that cannot be assailed by external foes.

original: jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
analyzed: jhānānam ābhicetasikānam diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārānam nikāma lābhī hoti a kiccha lābhī a kasira lābhī
translated: In the same way, when a noble disciple possesses seven good qualities and has attained the four jhānas, which are pleasant abidings in this very life, that are noble and emancipating, and which he has achieved through his own insight,

original: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako akaraṇīyo mārassa akaraṇīyo pāpimato.
analyzed: ayam vuccati bhikkhave ariya sāvako a karaṇīyaḥ mārassa a karaṇīyaḥ pāpimataḥ
translated: he is called a noble disciple who cannot be assailed by Māra, who cannot be assailed by the Evil One.

original: Katamehi sattahi saddhammehi samannāgato hoti?
analyzed: katamehi sattahi saddhammehi samannāgataḥ hoti
translated: What are the seven good qualities he possesses?

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.

translated: “So too, bhikkhus, a noble disciple is wise, possessing the wisdom that discerns arising and passing away, noble wisdom, which leads to the complete destruction of suffering.

original: Imehi sattahi saddhammehi samannāgato hoti.

translated: “He is endowed with these seven good qualities.

original: Katamesaṁ catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī?

translated: “He is one who obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the four jhanas that constitute the higher mind and provide a pleasant abiding here and now.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.

translated: “Suppose, bhikkhus, in a king’s frontier fortress there was a great store of grass, firewood, and water laid up, for the use of those who dwelt in the fortress, to prevent their going short and to ensure their comfort.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati

translated: “So too, bhikkhus, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

translated: “Just as in a king’s frontier fortress there is a large store of grass, timber, and water laid up for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of the men and for warding off outsiders,🔽so too, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhana, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

original: attano ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
analyzed: attanaḥ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsu vihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa
translated: This is his delight in that pleasure.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ tilamuggamāsāparaṇṇaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.

translated: “Just as in a king’s frontier fortress there is a large store of rice and barley laid up for the enjoyment, relief, and comfort of the men and for warding off outsiders,

original: attano ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
analyzed: attanaḥ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsu vihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa
translated: This is his happiness in the present.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rañño paccantime nagare bahuṁ bhesajjaṁ sannicitaṁ hoti, seyyathidaṁ—🔽sappi navanītaṁ telaṁ madhu phāṇitaṁ loṇaṁ abbhantarānaṁ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya bāhirānaṁ paṭighātāya.🔽Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva🔽somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave raññaḥ paccantime nagare bahum bhesajjam sannicitam hoti  sappi navanītam telam madhu phāṇitam loṇam abbhantarānam ratiyā a paritassāya phāsu vihārāya bāhirānam paṭighātāya  evam evam kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā eva  somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamāḥ adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttha
translated: “Just as in a royal frontier fortress there is a great deal of medicine stored up, such as ghee, fresh butter, oil, honey, molasses, and salt, for the use of the king’s men and for the protection of the king’s men,🔽so too, a noble disciple has a measure of wisdom. This is his happiness in the future.🔽“Again, a noble disciple, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous passing away of joy and displeasure, enters and remains in the fourth jhāna, neither painful nor pleasant, which has purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

original: jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati🔽attano ratiyā aparitassāya phāsuvihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa.
analyzed: jhānam upasampajja viharati 🔽attanaḥ ratiyā aparitassāya phāsu vihārāya okkamanāya nibbānassa
translated: This is his happiness in the present.🔽“Just as a royal frontier fortress is provided with a moat for the protection of those within and against intruders,🔽so too, a noble disciple has a measure of wisdom. This is his happiness in the future.

original: Imesaṁ catunnaṁ jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
